text:
I do a lot of agile coaching all of it remote these days. Since almost all companies at least in the US are doing some level of remote work now, it’s easy to find this type of opportunity from that standpoint, the harder part is finding the right fit.

It “works” but you have to be extremely strong on building trust and safe environments. If you just treat only like in-person it will likely be less than optimal and also less rewarding. Online techniques are key. Focus on how to maximize engagement and participation in every activity. Find ways to have them leading the meetings and not you. Find collaborative tools like miro and mural and many others that can encourage group participation. Avoid activities where one person types while everyone else waits or watches. There are probably a hundred other little tips but the main thing is use excessive amounts of empathy. Imagine yourself in their shoes. What would motivate you to engage, collaborate, focus? What would prohibit you or make it less likely? Good luck.

<@U88DG1JBY> either way, you need to maintain a candence of opportunities for connection.  Doesn’t always have to be complex.  For instance, I’ll sometimes tell teams I’m coaching I’ll be on 10 min early for a standup.  My reason: to talk about whatever they need.  Could be a key question, could be the weather or catching up on hobbies.

Online (whether we know people well or not), you need to be intentional on how you connect people.  Sometimes that’s providing”space” to connect and sometimes it involves providing “time” to connect.

Connection builds empathy; empathy builds psychological safety; psychological safety builds courage to raise the tough issues.

Set that pattern and they will learn to take it on as <@U3K3ESCA1> suggested.

I don't agree with "the project thing is an oxymoron if you're trying to do Scrum for example", at all. Projects can have their place, even in Scrum. Projects and products are just containers for work. But that's another discussion.

As far as your problem goes, if you have a portfolio of related products, you need a Portfolio Manager. This is probably a team, perhaps even comprised of representatives from each product, but with one person who can make the final decisions if things get deadlocked or time is of the essence. When you have a portfolio, you can't just have product teams going off and doing whatever they want. It's a balance between empowerment and guardrails.

That's one of them. There are a lot of skills that go into product management. Scrum distills it to expressing PBIs, ordering the backlog, ensuring visibility and transparency, ensuring the team understands the work, and optimizing the value of the work done by the Development Team. That last one alone is huge.

The skills needed for product management include requirements engineering (especially elicitation, analysis, specification, and management), market analysis, product strategy, schedule management, budget management, stakeholder communication, risk management...I'm sure I'm missing some. I even consider some aspects of UX design to be more closely related to product management than the technical development/delivery aspect, especially more in the UX research field. I just can't imagine one person being able to do all of these and do them well. And then if you add sales and marketing related work to this...

You run into the same problems at the portfolio level. However, you may be able to move some of the work up, depending on if the entire portfolio has the same or vastly similar target audience.

text:
Short answer, not in software development. Sure you can have a 40 people working on 1 product and you can have an overview dashboard. But you can’t have a team with 40 poeple.

I don’t know if the people writing about Kanban would lay out a ruleset allowing this, but it breaks  some principles from my perspective:
•  transparency: imagine a board with 20-40 tasks in doing. Sure for an overview of the PO it might be a good thing. But for the developers it’s just not practical.
• Normally in Kanban you do have dailies too, a daily of 40 people is awful. It will never work on a timebox and will only be awful reporting.
• Planning sessions, that also exist in Kanban would need to be done with 40 people this will take 2 days where most people won’t talk.
No seriously. Don’t have a “team” with 40 people. That is not a team but a crowd. Break em up, have the same PO, the same Agile Coach but not one board and one team. Have a separate session for an overview meeting if you want with everyone involved, but don’t do subtask planning, dailies or retros with 40 people.

text: I think your framework is not the problem, like Darren says. It’s more an issue of focus. Context switching has a huge toll on efficiency, quality and motivation. In your case I would rather switch to one week sprints only allow high prio bugs to be pushed into the sprint, all else should be defined in the sprint planning and I would make the sprint a sacred place, where there are no. interruptions to the devs. If you need them to consult often, set up recurring meetings with a timebox after or before lunch and don’t let them be interrupted on other times. Try to have the teams do just one project per team. So make the teams at least 4 people (better 5-7) big but if you have lots of contexts not bigger. Switch focus each sprint if necessary but if possible not during a sprint.

Those people will be more effective self organizing among a smaller group of people they get to know better, pair with, and ultimately bond with more. I would expect those 40 people to naturally build their own “teams” over time that just stick together and respond to a backlog of central work. And then....you’ll basically have a LeSS framework

A good book that will help you:

text:
I don't believe that there is such a thing as an "Agile coach" in the sense it is not a defined role in the definitions of Agile or Scrum.

Rather, it seems to me that it is the notion that one is a coach and one is coaching in the Agile space.

So realistically Agile coach is helping someone improve in some aspects of Agile principles.

Scrum came before Agile. Therefore it is not unreasonable to think of a Scrum Master as a more limited scope since the concepts of Scrum are more limited than Agile and the role of Scrum Master is more clearly defined.

However a Scrum Master is also supposed to be on a quest for improvement so it is not unreasonable to see much overlap in the skills and knowledge and even the  experience of the two roles, depending on the organization.

However, generally, a coach of Agile Development tends to hold a larger perspective than a single team, or even set of teams.  They are also not bound by Scrum principles, or concepts.

I would expect anyone to be a Scrum Master with a limited amount of training, the right attitude and willingness to learn.

For Agile Development coaches I expect more formal education in coaching and deeper understanding and appreciation of Agile and a broader knowledge of disciplines, methodologies, thought processes, approaches, implementation strategies.

To take this a step further Business Agility Coaches tend to have an even broader skillset, with understanding of org design, leadership, all or some business aspects including lean portfolio management as well as various areas of the business that are not traditionally considered Agile development such as HR, Finance, Marketing, etc.

If you are looking for a fixed list of skills you will find it but you won't find agile there. Agile coaching, scrum master, servant leader, facilitator,  etc, belong on a spectrum with a great amount of overlap depending on the culture and needs of the organization.

text:
Morning all, I've just tried a new way of prioritising a backlog. So far it's worked really really well, so I wanted to share it for peer review.

The backlog is logically ordered into features; each feature containing multiple fully formed stories.  The product has been well sliced, such that no feature is overly large (Deliverable in 1 - 2 sprints).

Rather than prioritising by story, the PO prioritises by feature.

During planning, the team then prioritise the order the stories, for the most important feature, are tackled; and which are brought into the next sprint

This has made prioritisation a lot faster, has improved PO engagement, has improved team ownership, has improved overall 'buy-in' and been a positive experience.

If this mehtod already exists please say, as I've not come across it before.

If not, I'm gonna call it the Wolff Method (Well.....it's worth a go, right?)

Chris, the issue you are hitting is you keep coming at this as a stated problem rather than an experiment. The more you do that, the less open you sound. I know you say you are willing to be wrong but it isn’t coming across that way. The humble thing to do is say “I feel Agile needs improvement, what do others think, would you like to discuss?” This is very different from saying “Agile needs an update.”

 It may be just wording but when you are talking about changing something so fundamental wording matters. I think back to the US Declaration of Independence and the phrase “All Men Are Created Equal. ” They didn’t sit around saying “all men, some men, all people, what’s the difference?” They knew exactly what they were saying. They knew that slavery still existed, they knew “men” left woman out but could be couched as men being used to mean people. They were precise and sensitive to their purpose and audience.

So when you talk about something as impactful as proposing changing a key document it is going to be assumed you will show care and precision in your words. This makes it impossible to not read meaning into what you are writing.

I can only answer for myself but I can tell you explicitly you are not rubbing me the wrong way. I can see your passion and I respect it. I do not know you well enough to know if you are more likely to take critique and adjust or take it and form a defense. I hope it’s the former but that’s just my bias, it’s not right or wrong.

I truly hope your experiment bares fruit.

Agile is customer-cetnric. Who is the customer asking for this? How are we collaborating with them?

I think we can agree Agile is not about building methodologies and it isn’t about building stuff for ourselves.

So I wish this wasn’t framed as “practice what we preach,” because it certainly isn’t what a lot of us preach. This feels more like I have a hammer and everything has now become a nail.

Experiment away, have fun, but can this be defined as an exploration of options vs an unfounded assertion that an update must happen?

I’ve been writing about post Agile mindset for over a year but that is about what is next, not what is wrong.

Agile does not need an update. It works. Perhaps you want to create something new and different for a different audience,  That’s fine. I would hope people are creative enough to come up with a name for it that isn’t going to create more confusion and complicate matters further.

I think being a leader in conversation and challenging norms is admirable. You nailed my concern though.

If we are going to take on something this important I do think wording and meaning precision is imperative.

If the challenge is partly “how do we make Agile clearer?” then we better be even clearer and more precise in our wording too, shouldn’t we?

For example “inspect and adapt” is a phrase associated with scrum, but the Agile version is broader.

The manifesto is called “Manifesto for Agile Software Development” it isn’t actually the “Agile Manifesto,” that is the short-hand used in the description of the principles but again if the goal is to get clearer at what we mean, then I’d start by being super precise and avoid short cutting terms and intended meanings even if it isn’t as snappy sounding.

Model the intent. Also inspect and adapt refers to inspecting data and outcomes. It doesn’t mean make some generalized assumption (like “manifesto needs an  update”) and then change based on it.

Certainly there is room for experiments, but that too isn’t inspect and adapt, it is the data that fuels the inspect and adapt.

Asserting “Agile needs an update” just feels offputting. It begs the question “Who says?”

What I think you mean to do, or at least I hope is to invite “Let’s explore the question, Does the Agile Manifesto for Software Development need an update?”

Posing it this way demonstrates openness, precision in language and purpose.

Just something to consider. Good luck.

text:
So, I've just been having a healthy debate on a LinkedIn post with Tobias Mayer and Jem Jelal and I'm keen on the thoughts of others here and contributions to the debate.

My view is that the Agile Manifesto needs an update. For the following reasons;

The statement at the beginning of the manifesto says "We are uncovering better ways of delivering software by doing it, and helping others do it"

Why does it need to be a historical artifact and not a living and breathing document which reflects what we as agile professionals have learned since its inception? As soon as we make something set in stone, we are missing opportunities to learn, and share that learning with others.

Are we saying that in 20 years, we haven't uncovered better ways? Are we saying that the manifesto only relates to software still? Even though it is now widely being applied within other industries?

Whilst the intent of the word 'Over' wasn't supposed to mean 'Instead of', how often have you observed antipatterns in the industry such as;

- Individuals and interactions over processes and tools - How often have you seen this interpreted to mean 'No process, or very little?' How do you enable a focus on the individual and enabling them to interact in this increasingly digital world?
- Working software over comprehensive documentation - People interpreting this to mean no documentation, or very little to the point of technical debt accruing which stalls progress.
- Customer collaboration over contract negotiation - How many metrics are there around frequency of customer collaboration? How is customer collaboration even measured?
- Responding to change OVER following a plan - People not planning at all, OR on the flip side, responding to change too frequently which can result in issues with context switching and reduce cycle time.

I'm not saying the manifesto needs a wholesale change. But perhaps we need to examine the language, tweak it slightly and acknowledge that it COULD be improved to make it better understood.

The counter argument;

I'd disagree on that. It is a historical artefact, not a living one. And "over" does not mean "instead of". All coders use tools. It would be impossible to do one's job  without them.
"X over Y" means focus more on X and less on Y. That's all.

What do you folks think?

text:
I've thought about this a bit.

I think at least one of the original authors have addressed this point and they said they see it as a snapshot in time and have no intentions of updating it.

To address some of your specific points:

The Manifesto was written by software developers. Just like how Lean had its roots in manufacturing and spread to other industries, Agility has its roots in software. If you look at specific instances of Lean - Lean Software Development, for example - you'll see transformations of the values and principles from Toyota's manufacturing environment into things that make sense for software development. You can probably do the same with Agile, but it wouldn't be a verbatim copy nor are the authors of the Agile Manifesto the most qualified to do that transformation.

The idea that "over" doesn't mean "instead of" is right in the Manifesto itself, when it says that is value in the items on the right.

I'd point out that there are also 12 principles. How many of those are still relevant today? My answer would be the vast majority of them, and the ones that need changes are mostly because of how time has passed. One example is business people and developers working together every day. Today, you can include other roles because of how the world has changed - DevOps is a good example of operations and infrastructure working with developers every day. The tools, technology, and skills to do that weren't widely available in the 1990s and early 2000s. Similarly, face to face conversations were favored because high fidelity voice, video, screensharing, and electronic forms of tools (whiteboards, for example) weren't widely available when the Manifesto was written.

I'd assert that all of the values and principles are perfectly relevant for agility today, with the most minor adjustments to account for the things that we are now capable of doing that just weren't possible when it was written.

text:
Thanks for the input <@UBUSZ4BQC>.

My main concern stems from the fact that there are a lot of agile professionals at the moment lamenting the current state of agile. Be it scaling frameworks, misunderstanding of the manifesto or otherwise, but we still then point back to the same snapshot in time document which hasn't been updated and expect people to use / coach it correctly.

Agile isn't a religion to be followed dogmatically.

We shouldn't be referring back to old texts and taking them as gospel. An extreme example of this would be the bible - _Thou shalt not let thy cattle gender with a diverse kind: thou shalt not sow thy field with mingled seed: neither shall a garment mingled of linen and woollen come upon thee."_ <https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Leviticus+19%3A19&version=KJV|Leviticus 19:19>

Do any of us not wear mixed fabric garments? We'd all be walking around naked.

The manifesto was a product of its time and the spirit of it is entirely relevant and remains so. I intend to work with some others, a more diverse group, to create an updated manifesto to reflect what we've learned as professionals in the last 20 years. We can improve it.

text:
Except for one line, I am struggling to see anything in the Manifesto that would require an update for people to be able to understand the values and principles. It seems like the problem is in the people doing the coaching not understanding the values and principles correctly, not the values and principles themselves.

For that, there's a good InfoQ book (it used to be free) called Understanding Agile Values and Principles - An Examination of the Agile Manifesto that really gets into what is meant by the different values and principles. It was written in 2019, so it does have a much more modern take on the state of the world in the 1990s and 2000s when the folks behind the Manifesto were doing the bulk of their work and how it compares to now.

Without knowing what changes you'd make, I don't see that much value in updating the Manifesto. It's more about making sure that people understand the values and principles and different ways to achieve agility, which doesn't require touching the Manifesto itself.

text:
The implication of “We are uncovering…” is that we are on a journey. The journey is never over. The manifesto is about discovery forever. It implies there is an arrogance in assuming we have the perfect answer. It’s why I never use the term “best practice”

And yes, we are saying the manifesto refers only to software. There are other types of Agile but they are not bound by the manifesto this was created specifically by looking at kanban, scrum, xtreme, etc and codifying what made them all work.

People have extrapolated, analogized into other areas but those areas should have their own manifestos. For example Agile HR should definitely have it’s own manifesto.

Business Agility for example is a whole other thing, with its own pillars and Technical Agility is merely one of the pillars.

I’m not saying there is no need to update the manifesto to more accurately reflect modern concerns and challenges. For example the Manifesto doesn’t deal with the importance of psychological safety, or the damaging effects of working with teams that don’t embrace agility.

So perhaps it does need updating but it should come from a place of refinement to support its original intent, not to expand the scope.

The scope was software. If people want to think it means more that’s up to them but that shouldn’t be the reason to expand it IMO.

As for people misinterpreting the manifesto  - that’s again their problem. You don’t change the roadmap because people don’t know what a road is. You educate them.

When I introduce Agile to a team I spend half a day dissecting the manifesto and the principles word by word, phrase by phrase. We have deep discussions and develop a strong shared understanding and sense of purpose.

I do this even if the team has been running scrum for five years and every time they learn a ton and change their mindset in those four hours. Every time. IMO very few teams or even “experts” really embrace what makes it work which is why there are so many places where it really doesn’t get maximum results.

I think generally, a lack of enlightenment, not the manifesto is the root cause of the disconnect.

The issues you bring up with each line describe the fundamental problem that most people have with Agile. It isn’t hard to get right, but people don’t want to. They want Agile to fit their existing structure and model with minimal impact. This is why they maintain command and control models while implementing scrum or spend so much time on velocity instead of outcomes. They aren’t measuring the right things, they aren’t getting the role of documentation and why that line in the manifesto is critical, they aren’t planning sufficiently or planning the right things.

This is not a flaw in the manifesto, it’s a flaw in organizational culture and the humans that defend it.

Sure words can be tweaked and we should question everything including the manifesto. However after working with hundreds of companies and countless teams I’m pretty convinced, any flaw you find is likely with the reader. Not because the wording is perfect or because the manifesto couldn’t be expanded. It is because the reader is  limited to the point that they need to catch up to the manifesto before we consider changing it.

In other words, it’s like the US Constitution.  From time to time amendments may be needed as we enhance social justice and society changes but we don’t dumb it down or rewrite because people are not well educated or don’t like it at a personal level.

People misinterpret the constitution all the time. It’s their problem, not the document.

So I’ll put this to you all, point to something significant that has changed in society that can not be addressed without altering the manifesto from its original intent. Then I’m open to change. Point to new ways Agile is being used and I lean towards calling that something else.

Agile as a term is overused, misunderstood and rarely practiced well. So I think the emphasis should be less on change and more on becoming better at educating people on its meaning.

If I wrote the manifesto I would have worded it differently, I would have had different emphasis as well.  I think the authors really missed the boat on the impact of external factors and human psychology. However I’m able to adapt those realities with Agile at the core of my approach. I don’t need to change it to do that.

I am not saying there is anything fundamentally wrong with the manifesto. As a historical document, a screenshot in time. It serves it's purpose. But does that mean it can't be better?

The manifesto was created by all male software engineers, whilst it doesn't devalue what they've created, it would be tough to argue that it represents diverse thinking.

My proposal - We create a refined version, not a wholesale re-write. We reflect on what we've learned from the original and the realities of the modern world.

This shouldn't be my voice alone, or even a few people. It should be crowdsourced. Our agile manifesto for 2020. A community led initiative without any individual owners or names on it.

I intend to facilitate such a movement and will see how I can get people involved.

I see it as a refinement, not a re-write.

Just like a user story, we create it based on our understanding at the time. The agile manifesto was the user story of its time. It had a purpose, was created from the lens of a group of white male software engineers.

We have learned over the years and what we've learned is that the manifesto is either misinterpreted, or mistaught.

My view is that we should explore this further. Crowdsource as a community what refinements the manifesto should have. To reflect the current era, people and to include a wider range of diversity.

If the community feel it doesn't need change? So be it. We've simply followed the spirit of the manifesto ourselves by inspecting and adapting.

Taking no action is a decision. I don't want to force anyone to be involved, but I feel a community led version of the manifesto which reflects the peoples view would be more relevant than a 20 year old document which hasn't been maintained in the spirit which it espouses.

text:
Talking this abstractly is difficult, at least for me.

Personally, I see only two things that I'd change:
• "Business people and developers must work together daily throughout the project." This should be more inclusive, for the reader's sake. Test specialists don't see themselves as developers. Operations folks don't see themselves as developers. UX designers don't see themselves as developers. It's true what <@U3K3ESCA1> said that they all develop something, and I can usually get them to see that, but it would make it easier. On the flip side, "business people" includes customers and users who may not see themselves as "business people". It boils down to a need for close collaboration among all relevant stakeholders throughout the effort.
• "The most efficient and effective method of conveying information to and within a development team is face-to-face conversation." I think this is true, but it's also not helpful, especially looking back on the last few months. Face-to-face may be the most efficient and effective, but it's not always right for the business. Better tools - higher fidelity video and voice chat, screen sharing, electronic whiteboards, various improvements to asynchronous communication tools - have made being apart less painful than it was in the 1990s and early 2000s. I don't know what the right balance between tradeoffs it, but I do know that the idea that "you can't be agile with distributed teams" is wrong, and this point gives off that kind of vibe.
Every other thing brought up here is more of a people issue that can't really be helped by changing anything in the Manifesto itself. I would feel that anyone who spent 15 minutes to read and think about the words written and then some more time challenging their own assumptions about the world would get through these problems. A good coach - someone who truly understands the values and principles as they were written and how time has affected them - would be beneficial.

On the flip side, "business people" includes customers and users who may not see themselves as "business people". It boils down to a need for close collaboration among all relevant stakeholders throughout the effort.

"The most efficient and effective method of conveying information to and within a development team is face-to-face conversation." I think this is true, but it's also not helpful, especially looking back on the last few months. Face-to-face may be the most efficient and effective, but it's not always right for the business. Better tools - higher fidelity video and voice chat, screen sharing, electronic whiteboards, various improvements to asynchronous communication tools - have made being apart less painful than it was in the 1990s and early 2000s. I don't know what the right balance between tradeoffs it, but I do know that the idea that "you can't be agile with distributed teams" is wrong, and this point gives off that kind of vibe.

Every other thing brought up here is more of a people issue that can't really be helped by changing anything in the Manifesto itself. I would feel that anyone who spent 15 minutes to read and think about the words written and then some more time challenging their own assumptions about the world would get through these problems. A good coach - someone who truly understands the values and principles as they were written and how time has affected them - would be beneficial.

If we take the spirit of the manifesto and its principles as it was intended, WE are the self organising teams, WE the community should be committed to regularly reflect on how the manifesto can be more effective, to meet OUR needs and refine it accordingly. 

As an agile coach, one of the measures of my own success is whether the team or organisation can continue with good habits in my absence. I exist to make myself redundant. 

What if the lack of update of the manifesto over these last 20 years has been the same litmus test performed by the creators? What if they are waiting for us to learn, self organise and refine it to reflect the modern times without their interference.

If we take the spirit of the agile manifesto as it was intended, then nothing, even the holy manifesto should be immune from inspection.

Join me in the movement. Let me know here if you'd like to be involved. I will organise a wholly inclusive event. A community wide retrospective on the agile manifesto and whether it needs to be updated. 

If it doesn't? That's ok. We as a community have agreed that that's the case.

But that doesn't mean we shouldn't wait another 20 years to determine otherwise.

Call for others to join and be involved. This will then become an updated manifesto, the 2020 edition.

The original creators of the manifesto have all moved on. Created their own frameworks, their own interpretation of how the manifesto should be applied, why shouldn't we?

So perhaps I'm not making myself clear. I'm not saying agile itself is a development project. It's a mindset. But does that mean we can't inspect and adapt it?

Why has the last 20 years not been an experiment on whether the manifesto itself is right?

My proposal is simply this. Let's examine the manifesto as a community. I don't believe we have meaningfully done this and I believe that we should.

You can call this an emotional reaction. Anecdotal.. But I am seeing a lot of people in the community saying that A. The manifesto isn't known about enough. B. It isn't being applied correctly. This in itself is the beginnings of data, it just isn't collected and arranged empirically.

I don't believe in always getting data before acting. Data guides decision making, but it shouldn't be our only influence.

If the outcome of this is that a number of people get involved, they vote on whether they feel there is a need for change, they collaborate together on refinements to the manifesto, wonderful. Theres some evidence, the vox populi have spoken.

Voting for change without data is seems like preference. It’s the difference between running an experiment and releasing based on the findings from your experiments.

We may experiment without data, but finalizing something that affects millions of people without data simply isn’t wise.

Nothing run with running experiments, have two organizations try running different versions of the manifesto and see what happens. Sounds fun.

Whenever any of my teams make a fundamental change   I ask them to be clear on why the change, impact of change and expected outcome of change. I then ask them to timebox the change - try it for a period of time and then reflect on the data. Did we move towards the expected outcome? Were there unintended consequences? Running Agile manifesto adjustment experiments sounds fun. Changing the manifesto without that data sounds like preference, not improvement.

All I have seen here today is complaints about people having comprehension issues. I haven’t heard one demonstrable problem with the manifesto. Since empirically it does work and has been applied successfully it’s hard to listen to people exerting opinion over fact.

So let's consider it an experiment. Review the existing manifesto as a community, create an alternative and then use it with some companies and see if it results in empirical data to justify change.

The way I see it, even if a new version is created, that doesn't mean people have to blindly follow it. They can continue with the old version if they wish.

Just like with a new team doing a retrospective, they take what input they have at the time, they propose actions and experiments to try next and they then analyse whether the hypothesised outcome has yielded results.

My hypothesis is that an updated manifesto with a more diverse group of creators, created by the community rather than a group of individuals, would result in a more relevant version of the manifesto for the people using it. We can even agree as a community how we'll measure whether or not it has resulted in improvements and we can review these at the next time we review the manifesto. 

This to me represents a more accurate translation of the spirit of the manifesto than just leaving it as is because we don't yet have the data to support otherwise.

Happy to be proven wrong  :)

I'd like to facilitate that experiment and see what happens.

It's not just that the intent is lost. The manifesto was the product of its age. Written exclusively through the lens of middle class, white software developers. 

That isn't culturally diverse and I'd argue it doesn't represent todays situation. This isn't about cancellation culture and forcing diversity but simply practicing what we preach about inspecting and adapting regularly.

Considering unconditional positive regards, I don't believe there was any ill intent from the creators, simply that they were hampered by their own biases and limiting beliefs.

Where is psychological safety in the manifesto? Is the language fit for purpose? Is it still relevant to software and projects? 

Let's examine the alternatives, identify the metrics we'll track to see if any alternative brings value and then use that as input into the next review. That's all.

We don't always need data to take action. We should favour data over subjectivity and emotion but not use a lack of data to excuse decision paralysis.

text:
I think part of the disconnect is the phrasing of what is being asked.
We know without a doubt that an agile mindset “works,” because many are seeing direct and measurable benefits from all aspects of it.
We know beyond any reasonable doubt that the agile manifesto does support many strong practices and has moved development forward.

1. What we don’t know is if it is reasonable to apply those principles to every single domain and expect similar success when applied appropriately. 
2. We also don’t know if changing the wording without changing the meaning would result in a better outcome in terms of more teams behaving as intended by the Agile principles and manifesto.
3. We also don’t know if changing the principles or manifesto itself to have different meaning or emphasis may result in better outcomes.

For #1 the experiment is simple, pick a domain, apply all the agile principles correctly driven by someone who is experienced but not in the cult of agile.
For #2 I don’t see the value. I mean we know it works so if a lot of people don’t get it, it’s their problem. Also, keep in mind most people who struggle are struggling because of external factors such as leadership or organizational design or lack of customer engagement, culture, etc. So changing words without changing meaning won’t fix most issues.
For #3 I think I have a different concern. I see Agile as stated working great. There isn’t one company I have gone in that doesn’t do it better when I leave. So I know with proper instruction the Agile principles get companies the results they want and expect. Therefore, any change to those principles needs to be well defined in terms of benefits that are lacking and results that are unachievable with the current principles.

If someone can show me any aspect of agile software development that can be better universally if the principles were altered then I’m interested. If they are trying to apply principles in ways they are not intended then just call it something else. Be creative, create your own methodology and don’t hijack what works. I’m not speculating that agile works and I highly believe in the principle if it ain’t broke don’t fix it.

So I think this begins by being transparent about the goal - is it create something new or solve a problem for a different domain or is it just apply preference to something that is working for so many people. People should feel free to do all of the above as long as they don’t confuse creation with improvement or necessity with preference.

This whole thread made me think of:

<https://www.psychologytoday.com/au/blog/head-strong/201605/the-3-c-s-trust|Trust = Competence + Character + Caring>

However competence is not as simple as being competent. It’s perception. Even when people are incompetence we can perceive them as competent <https://hbr.org/2019/03/to-seem-more-competent-be-more-confident|because they were confident>.

Therefore, competence is actually more a perception of competence as related to other factors including an individuals confidence.

Making the first statement be more accurately:

Trust = Confidence (Perceived Competence) + Character + Caring

text:
Ok cool. As you can probably tell with that formula my head space went down the path of ‘confidence’ is important as it relates to building trust.

Research would suggest that in order to build trust people need to perceive you as competent (able to do the job, to lead them). Which makes confidence important as you need to display a level of confidence in your demeanour, decisions, actions, etc to perpetuate this notion of competence.

Paradoxically competence can both hinder but also improve confidence. Dunning–Kruger effect is first as it hinders confidence but then eventually through repetitive success you will increase your confidence. Sometimes this is just luck and perhaps naive confidence but other times it’ll be time-tested.

However factoring in the other two thirds of the ‘trust’ equation confidence needs to be counter-balanced by humility, vulnerability and authenticity - much which has been discussed above.

Too much confidence and it will erode trust - now you’re just arrogant. Too little confidence and too much vulnerability and you seem unsure and do not instil competence.

So perhaps my hypothesis at the end of reading the conversation so far is that it’s about balance in order to cultivate trust. As without trust you cannot lead.

Still thinking but that’s where the question came from. Perhaps it goes deeper because trust is a two way street?

text:
Before thinking of how to measure, think of what and why. How is most flexible and doesn't always need a data driven measurement. Sometimes opinions and surveys are enough. A retro is common form of "evaluation".

Why: We want T shaped skills so that we can...

What: Our first steps are to...

Result: Those steps are completed. After meeting together and discussing how it went, we have decided to... 

I once was taught to think of T shaped as icicles. Distribution of water/skills results with side icicles growing while longer icicle shrinks. I think many assumptions lead to forgetting the shrinking part.

I have seen the strategy of having the team define what the ideal/end state looks like make next step discovery align with a team purpose, and that ends up moving the team far more than an x of y approach, simply because of having a meaningful vision. Apply that mentality to the desire to measure. How would a team normally measure customer satisfaction? Then consider the team as the customer? Distance/growth matters far less when satisfaction is low.

text:
I understand the concept. I just haven’t had that experience. I started my first software company at 17. I was surrounded by people far more experienced than me and while they often referred to me with names like “the genius” I always felt like I knew nothing. 

Later I went to work at a company filled with real geniuses and I always felt like the dumbest guy in the room. I loved it. I loved soaking it up all the time. 

Later, as a consultant I was often brought in for my expertise in some technology. Yet I still always felt like a sponge, learning from every situation.

Today, with 35 years of experience I’m often asked for my advice and my best advice is never stop learning. While experience does lead to confidence, I’ve never considered myself anything but a student who loves to share. I’ve never known or been interested in mastery, only improvement and growth interest me.

I don’t know why I never traveled through the imposter syndrome but I suspect it’s because I’ve never had a problem saying “I don’t know” and I try to always assume I’m wrong first and then worked the problem backwards. 

I think this has allowed me to have the confidence to try with conviction, while remaining humble enough to admit I may not have all the answers. I think it helped me develop a patience for others’ mistakes as well. 

I used to get irritated with mistakes, especially when they seemed obvious. However now I celebrate mistakes. I find them the best part of us because it’s where we have the most opportunity to learn from each other.

This organisation had been undergoing an Agile Modernisation and Transformation programme of work for over 3 years to date. Despite a roll out of large scale classroom based training courses, the agile adoption was mixed and also missed out large groups in the management and leadership levels of this organisation.

What emerged from this meeting was not a training plan, but a Learning Manifesto where we value:

The original signatories to this Learning Manifesto were myself, Darryl Sherborne Robin McAlpine and Ian Banner  We invite you and others that share our vision to also become signatories.

Failure swap shop concept.

A hugely important topic for me at the moment is failure, and after my last 'Failure swap shop' failed to gain much traction, I figure it's time to try again.

The only way we can erode the stigma around failure, is to become desensitised to it. To share, embrace and communicate about our failures more often. This is where the 'Failure swap shop' concept comes in. How does this work? Simply share a failure you've experienced and what you learned from it within this post.
 
I'm going to be more deliberate about this attempt with the swap shop this time also and call out some fellow practitioners of mine to respond to the challenge. I'm tagging some of those who I've worked with, those who I feel are particularly open to failure and therefore I think will embrace the opportunity to share.

Over to you - Learn fast, learn often.

text:
Is there any thinking behind when to expand the scope of a single product versus launch a second product?

Let's go into a hypothetical world that doesn't have stuff like Microsoft Office. I'm working on word processing software and built it, ship it, and people love it. Instead of using paper, they are now typing their documents up and sharing them electronically. However, some customers are now asking for a spreadsheet. I have a few options. I could refuse and focus on word processing only, letting someone else capture the spreadsheet market. I could build a spreadsheet into the existing product (this is much like how Microsoft Works was set up). I could create a second product and manage them totally independently. I could build a spreadsheet product and integrate it into a product portfolio.

Each of these choices has different impact to organizational and team structure, organizing and planning the work items, release planning, releasing/deploying, and so on.

Is there any significant discussion of evaluating options and tradeoffs in each of these options?

<@U010GKG17HN> you want an answer in a way you can’t get here. The reason for it is that you want a recipe for an uncharted area. It’s like saying the amount of work in a cake without defining which cake you want to bake.
Spikes are exploratory tasks to define unknown areas, there is just one factor to measure success:
*The team has gathered enough knowledge to make decisions based on the spike.*
If this has not happened the spike was a failure, if this has happened it was a success. If you want to get into the grey areas, *the success can be measured by the confidence the team now has to solve the issue that triggered the spike.* How can you measure team confidence? Ask the team how they feel, that’s about it.
There is really nothing else to measure success upon, unless you want to measure the exact time invested, which should be timeboxed and not open, so it makes little sense. In my opinion there are no factors, not even the criteria is relevant at the end, because the goal is to solve a problem, if you manage to find a way with just meeting a few of the AC’s but with very high confidence, your spike was a real success.

text: The outcome of a spike is successful if it allows us to move forward. Typically I use spikes to time box research with the expectation of some sort of outcome. The outcome is determined by the findings. It may be the outcome is simply ruling out an option. It may be a identification of more spikes or stories that need to be developed. The outcome may be a solution to a problem or a reasonable estimate that can be used for decisions.  The only way a spike fails is if we learn nothing at all. That would be unacceptable. I suppose another failure would be if we don’t adhere to our time box, but that’s true of everything in Scrum.

text:
<@U010GKG17HN> you want a hard distinction between factors and acceptance criteria. First acceptance criteria in a research task are very volatile, as I said you may think you need them all and find out you were starting with a wrong assumption and the answer is much simpler with something undefined, so I would be very careful with being too strict about those. As I said above and sweiner confirmed, success means we have confidence enough to move forward.
Now you want the academic answer from a circle of practitioners (maybe not the best idea) and want to know which factors in a spike lead to better spike handling. Those factors do not define the content of the spike but only the generic outline to be successful.
My best take on the *factors*:
• openness on the problem statement and the solution 
• experience of the assigned team members
• communication about issues while researching
• backup from team
• clearness on the issue to solve
• awareness of time constraints and time investment
• ability to compromise on solutions
Was this what you were searching for? Hope it helps.

First acceptance criteria in a research task are very volatile, as I said you may think you need them all and find out you were starting with a wrong assumption and the answer is much simpler with something undefined, so I would be very careful with being too strict about those. As I said above and sweiner confirmed, success means we have confidence enough to move forward.
Now you want the academic answer from a circle of practitioners (maybe not the best idea) and want to know which factors in a spike lead to better spike handling. Those factors do not define the content of the spike but only the generic outline to be successful.
My best take on the
factors
openness on the problem statement and the solution
experience of the assigned team members
communication about issues while researching
backup from team
clearness on the issue to solve
awareness of time constraints and time investment
ability to compromise on solutions
Was this what you were searching for? Hope it helps.

text:
I think the reason we are responding this way is there are unintended consequences to rewarding the obvious. Look at the root cause. Why aren’t they motivated? It isn’t because they didn’t get a prize. It’s because they don’t have a shared sense of purpose, it is because they don’t feel they have significant autonomy to make decisions or take risks, it’s because they aren’t provide enough opportunities to learn new skills and share their knowledge with others, and it’s because they are siloed and don’t feel a connection to larger purpose.

When you reward individuals or single teams you are setting up a zero sum game. For me to win you have to lose.

Of course that’s not your goal but when we focus on the easy targets we create unintended dynamics.

Instead, ask why would someone get out of bed every day and try to do their best? I promise you it isn’t for a prize. However, you figure out what it is an you will discover how to motivate them effectively.

When I was young I worked for Steve Jobs. I came in early and left late. We had champagne and strawberries often on Fridays and we worked in a luxurious office that looked more like a museum. More significant was the caliber of people I worked with, brilliant, driven, focused on a single purpose.

I was a kid living in a dream. I would have done anything to stay there. I would almost have worked for free.

Steve told us we were changing the world, and we believed it. It wasn’t just hype, it was who we were as a group. We weren’t creating a better UI or easier development tools. We were changing the world and our friends and family would benefit from our efforts.

Never got a prize and frankly I would have felt insulted if I did. Someone who believes they are making a difference in the universe doesn’t need trinkets. They need to be in the center of the action.

text:
Competing with each other may be “fun” but it isn’t going to create a feeling of connectedness with a larger mission. People need purpose, fun is simply enjoying what you are doing. You can enjoy your work when it feels meaningful and important and rewarding to you.

If people are feeling like work is no fun, I promise you it’s not because they want a prize. It’s because they don’t feel connected to something important enough. I’m asking you to consider the heavy lift of connection instead of the quick win of reward.

It’s the difference between giving someone a sugary drink vs healthy meal.
Rewards are fun but they aren’t long lasting, they don’t fill people with a sense of loyalty or purpose and they don’t solve the underlying problem.

Fill their soul and fun will come.  Connect them to a purpose, give them more of a voice and make them feel safe to take risks and use that voice and make sure they are being challenged in positive ways to grow and share their knowledge. 

If you want to reward them, reward them for helping each other. Don’t pit them against each other. Make it a reward we all win or we all miss. At least this way there is common purpose.

I highly recommend considering a session of triz or some other liberating structure. Solving a problem together can be hilarious fun and motivating and productive.

Many of the companies I have seen institute pure fun remote events end up demotivating people. It feels forced and mandatory even when it’s not. As leaders we must be vigilant about the unintended consequences of our well-meaning actions.

If you really want to support your teams. Have them self organize an event and the rewards for it. That way at least they take ownership of it. Still, it’s not going to replace having a clear and motivating purpose.

I’ve also had many of these conversations of late and we decided to do a mixture of what I suggested above but to also do a series of surveys and interviews to better understand everyones unique situations and context.

The biggest learning they had was just how different everyones situations are - from people alone in an apartment to others working out of their garage to find a quiet place away from their kids. Some feel “super productive” whilst others are feeling overwhelmed and exhausted from back-to-back zoom calls….

Again your context will be different but I guess my suggestion is to talk to people and find out what challenges they are facing and then ideate with them around potential solutions.

text:
<@U4WMQ58V9>Don’t read too much into the idea of “customer value”. Value is something where the customer perceives value and can provide feedback. So if you have a working ability to drop a file in a share, then that is something the customer can provide feedback on if they like the way it works.

This is about feedback and learning. Delivery is of course the goal but working software and delivered software are not the same thing. Get something small working that the customer finds useful in a larger context, and then get feedback.

From the feedback iterate on what is important or move on to the next step. A workflow like you defined is a reasonable approach to break it down. The other approach would be to get something simplistic working from end to end then refine it further.

We often fall into the all or nothing trap when we hear “customer value,” break the problem down in such a way you can deliver something that works that the customer can react to as they would in the real world.

Your goal early on should be feedback and shared understanding. Once the key pieces are in place you can refine the feedback for details. At least that is one approach that is effective.

My Product Manager refuses to use the backlog 'conventionally'. Instead, they are planning the next 5 sprints, with goals, and adding issues in each one. They are even creating sprints for 'needs refining' and 'refined' so that the backlog can be a personal notepad....
We've addressed the issue a few times and each time it gets a bit better but, i suspect, pressure from the business to have a plan defaults their behaviour back (or even makes it worse). It's becoming very command & control and the team are lacking ownership over their own sprints... anyone had a similar experience or have any ideas to help me?

text:
I can understand the idea of having pre planning, and this is pretty good as long as it is a “working” document that is changed each sprint by the team’s decisions.
What I mean is that there can be a “long term road map”. The thing is it should not default to the truth and to pressure. You have to make it very clear that the only thing that is given to devs is a priotized list. They only estimate the next in the worst case the 2 upcoming sprints and they decide alone on sprint planning what really goes in. If this is respected than the “big planning” will become something dependent on the team. If it’s not very accurate (which is most times the case) it will loose meaning. If it is accurate it’s great for everyone.
Key point: Make the team decide what goes in, don’t show them the whole roadmap and make the PO/PM respect the team’s decisions.

Often with this kind of plans reengineering and bugfixing comes too short, so you might want to keep an eye on that.

Looking at the descriptions I get the impression that you do not really understand what you can actually influence / manage. 
Risk has two dimensions that you can influence. One is the magnitude of the impact (if that happens, how bad can it get, e.g. a range from 1 to a 100 million USD) and two, the frequency of occurrence (how often can this happen, e.g. a range from once a year to 50 times per year). In addition, you have probability ranges e.g. There is an 80% probability of a risk occurring twice a year that would result in max. impact). So I think a better text for the top right quadrant would be "Do whatever you can to reduce or mitigate the impact and/or frequency of occurrence of that risk."

Risk has two dimensions that you can influence. One is the magnitude of the impact (if that happens, how bad can it get, e.g. a range from 1 to a 100 million USD) and two, the frequency of occurrence (how often can this happen, e.g. a range from once a year to 50 times per year). In addition, you have probability ranges e.g. There is an 80% probability of a risk occurring twice a year that would result in max. impact). text:
Also when dealing with complex networks / applications it becomes virtually impossible (way to expensive) to evaluate every possible risk (including its impact and frequency of occurrence and probability distribution) because you have cascading /ripple effects. So in supply chain management (the management of complex global supply chains with dozens of companies involved) we have learned that it is very hard to deal with risk because you never know how bad the impact will be and how often it might occur (though Monte Carlo Sims can help here) and where in the chain it will occur. So we do two things. 
1. We monitor high impact and high frequency risks and there we actively try to reduce impact and frequency proactively 
2. We ask ourselves, how can we set up our supply chains / operation in a way that in case we are getting hit by one of these high impact risks, we have the fastest possible time at reasonable costs to recovery? (recovery being the state that you had prior to the impact). So these are questions around network design, facility design, backup suppliers & facilities, flexibility in mode of transport, and where in the system it makes sense to build redundancy and safety stocks.

text: I am working as a Agile Coach and just started working with one team, they have already been working on agile since last 4 years. I did GEMBA walk and have noted observations. Just I was looking for best way to present it with corrective actions. Any suggestions or references, templates?

elements.text: I am working as a Agile Coach and just started working with one team, they have already been working on agile since last 4 years. I did GEMBA walk and have noted observations. Just I was looking for best way to present it with corrective actions. Any suggestions or references, templates?

text:
How long have you been working with the team and how long have you observed them? Is the team holding regular retrospectives?

First, if you haven't observed the team for at least an iteration or two, I don't think you've observed for long enough. Unless something is seriously wrong, I would make sure that you've observed for long enough. Once you've spent enough time observing, I'd recommend using the retrospective as an opportunity to see if the team agrees with what you've observed and wants to do anything about it.

I'd be very cautious about presenting it as a "corrective action". The team may not agree that what you observe is a problem. It could be an effective way for them to work. I'd recommend posing questions to understand why things are the way they are first, and seeing if the team has solutions to any problems.

One modification to that script is to avoid the word “you”. Instead, try “there tends to be a lot of stories carried to next sprint,” or “how often is the sprint  backlog completely delivered by end  of sprint?”

“You” can be heard as blame.  This is a detail that I have found supported a less bias facilitation. I can feel a difference in the level of defensiveness when we are all on the same side of the table looking at the issues together instead of me pointing my finger at them, even if I’m well meaning. 

Of course it depends on your group how much this matters, but with s team you are new with I'd suggest keeping this in mind.

text:
I leave. Two devs don’t need a scrum master.

As to your actual question I would reflect with the team on why we missed the deadline, how we can improve and what specific actions we will take to improve. Then I would share the plan with the stakeholders. Keep in mind, it is likely the issue is partly caused by people outside your group and if they aren’t willing to also improve there is only so much you can do.

text:
Think of facilitation as a role of minimization. Ask yourself, “How can I run X with as light a touch as possible?” So if I’m running a CoP event, ask, “how can we determine a topic with me doing the least amount possible?”

The answer has already been mentioned above. Trust the team and set expectations high. Ask the CoP to solve for topic. That way they are engaged and own the decision. This will lead to better outcomes and allow you to model the very behavior you expect from them.

Still if you want ideas I like the provocative        ones. For example, how can we get rid of our managers? Why do we bother estimating? Does it matter if we don’t have a prioritized sprint backlog? Can Scrum be successful with no leadership buy-in? How do we deal with dependencies that are not agile?

Got an interesting one...and this is purely a discussion and debating point. Last weekend I was watching the film Widow Maker (Basically a Hollywood interpretation of a nuclear disaster on a 1960's Russian nuclear sub). Early on in the film there's an accident and the Captain says to the first officer 'Who is responsible for this?', the first officer refuses to give the name of the office in charge and instead replies giving the captain's name. Later there is a nuclear accident and a similar incident occurs. This time the captain finds the nuclear officer and tells him to get a team, no matter their rank, and work out how to solve this problem....all sorts of good Agile mind sets going on there.

But this brings me to my question / debating point:  We all believe that no one person should be blamed after an incident, and that all 'problems' are opportunities to improve a process or learn.  But do we feel this applies to more extreme situations? Consider a nuclear accident, or a medical incident where someone dies...situations where there is a very human need to blame (which can also help in mental acceptance / recovery of the family). Does the 'no blame' approach work here? (i think it's a given that there is also a learning opportunity).

text:
I am not convinced that blame helps with acceptance of reality after accidents. Let's assume for a moment it does.
It doesn't actually mean there is a link between blame and truth or facts.

I also don't think '_we all believe that no one person should be blamed after an incident_' is a justified generalisation.

I personally believe no one should be blamed or kept responsible (without investigation) if there are doubts, especially if a person in question does not feel so.
That's why accidents/incidents are followed by analysis of complex situation and contributing factors that try to assess what happened and why.

There are 'clearer' cases where someone deliberately does X and we can be curious about influencing factors, and there are complex cases where groups of people wanted the best and it is not clear who contributed and how.

text:
I assume we are discussing a mistake, not blatant incompetence or unethical behavior.  When split second judgement is concerned and a mistake is made I don’t know what blame buys you.

In that case I think blameless always works because it is solution focused. Is the goal blame or solution? Is the problem the individual or the system they work in?

Blaming the CEO is no better than blaming the shareholders. They are the fools who invested in him/her and then decided to make a change when things went poorly. Why get rid of the person who learned something?

The reason we blame is we are weak, lazy and ignorant. It’s like beating a dog for peeing on the rug. Or yelling at the dog for barking.

It may make us feel better but it’s cruel and ineffective even if in the moment it seems to resolve an issue.

“What did we learn? How will we improve ,” has to be the objective, doesn’t it? Otherwise we are sending the message - you can’t innovate, you can’t take risks.

We live in glass houses yet always seem at the ready with our stones.

It also sends the message don’t bother being loyal to the organization because  the organization certainly won’t be loyal to you.

text: I actually know the answer to this re: “high reliability organizations” such as nuclear power plants and other circumstances where you can tolerate exactly zero mishaps - you don’t just promote a no blame culture, you reward people for admitting mistakes and finding weaknesses. You have to learn from small mistakes to never make large ones, and learn from close calls as much as you can, since a single serious incident is completely unacceptable. Check out for example <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3388695/>

text:
Scrum in particular is completely data driven. Measuring what matters is key, I like that you are trying to get to a shared understanding by asking probing questions however there is an easier way to look at this.

Whenever you see an adjective or adverb in an objective you need to define it. You need to measure it. You need to bound it.

When you say “increase value” you must convert that to “increase value by X”  Now you are right, if you don’t know where you are you certainly don’t know where you are going or even how you would get there.

I’ll also argue you are not in an agile transformation, not yet. Until you are clear on what you are trying to do you are learning but that is not in itself transformation.

If you want to be in an agile transformation you must have a sense of what you want to change and WHY. So it is the WHY here that is first missing, then the WHAT. The WHY is the purpose, the motivation, the thing that shall align all forces on a single goal. Without it, transformation is just  a word.

Once you have your deeper WHY you can start to look at WHAT should change. WHAT is the measures, the things you value are the things you measure. They are your WHAT.

Once you have discovered the WHAT, with your WHY at the core you will need to collaborate and define HOW.

The key to agility is Lead with WHY, Align around WHAT and Trust the teams with HOW

As an aside, note that the WHEN will fall out of this process eventually, but keep in mind, transformation is an iterative process and your destination will continue to change as you learn and your environment impacts you.

So be prepared for everything to be altered. HOWEVER if you change your WHY, it’s potentially a complete reset. It’s much easier to stay true to your purpose and change how you measure success.

Still, if you change your WHAT you will greatly impact the best way to achieve your goals and it will impact behavior as well.

This means HOW will be impacted if WHAT changes. This is why Agile teams are focused on constantly improving HOW they work, rather than WHAT they value. They tend to change their metrics less often so they can be more predictable and increase their speed as a team.

Agility across an organization of course involves a lot more which is a good thing for us enterprise strategists but those are the basics.

Enjoy.

<@U4WMQ58V9> WHAT is my stand in for value, that is the things you value enough to measure. If you change the things you measure this means you are changing what you value. This will result in changes in approach, HOW.

For example if I have a team that I feel is delivering too slow I may choose to measure their velocity because I have determined that matters. I may tell them ” I will give you a bonus if you increase your velocity 20% more story points”  The result? The team will start over estimating their story points so their velocity goes up.  When the WHAT changes, the HOW changes. If the team doesn’t connect with the WHAT or doesn’t see how it directly contributes to the WHY then they will find a way to satisfy the WHAT but HOW they do it may not please you. Alignment of WHY, WHAT, HOW is critical for real agility.

text:
How can adding up value of teams possibly tell you how the org is doing? If one team creates a ton of research projects but deliver nothing to an actual customer, have they created value? If a team develops a database but it is never released to a customer because the UI was never completed are they delivering value? Why does it matter what the parts do, why isn’t what value you provide the customer not a sufficient measure? When we measure individual teams, they will optimize for their own silo. They will collaborate less and create more impediments.

For example, a compliance team may get very efficient at evaluating compliance but they may do it by forcing other teams through a cumbersome evaluation process so the Compliance team can be efficient. This could lead to a very slow delivery to customers but fast compliance. This is a common nightmare.  What would be better is if Compliance did not view their work as separate and only measure them by speed of which Compliant software gets to customers and those customers are satisfied.

When you optimize for the parts, you usually de-optimize the whole. This is why I see measuring of teams very difficult to achieve without negative unintended consequences. There are ways of doing both measurements and still be focused on the whole but it requires strong Agile leadership and enormous trust of teams to self organize.

The need to measure teams externally is a command and control mentality and for the most part represents transactional leadership, not transformation leadership.

If measurement of teams is necessary I recommend using and OKR model but I highly caution you not to tie OKR to any type of reward or punishment model. It will completely defeat the purpose.

<@U4WMQ58V9> What you measure in a transformation is what you value about the transformation. This should be determined before any attempt at transformation is attempted. It is how you align your purpose with your expected outcomes.

I would keep it simple but measurable. So when you say you want to measure “how is company doing” you need to define how you will measure that. Is it customer satisfaction? Product adoption? Employee satisfaction? Profitability? Product quality? Flow of new product innovation? Reduction of bottlenecks in process? 

There are many ways to determine how a company is doing. The ones you choose to measure tell everyone what you value. Also if you pick too many then you don’t really know what you want. There must be a priority and focus for an effective transformation. 3-5 metrics is typically as many as people can handle.

Imagine if your automobile had 35 gauges in it that you needed to pay attention to while you were driving to avoid a crash. Also imagine there was interplay between the gauges -  if you drive one value up you might drive another value down too much. How likely would you be to stay on the road with that to keep your eye on?

What happens is as you add more top line metrics people get confused about which ones matter when there is a conflict. For example is quality more important than speed? Maybe. 

They both matter but if we have to hit both we may hit neither. We may not even try if it looks impossible. Personally, I think in a transformation quality should be more important than speed. Organizations need to learn to go slow in order to speed up. 

However, this is a choice, a preference on my part and you may choose to measure speed. The implication is when you have optimized quality your overall speed and capacity should increase since less defects and customer issues. Yet, if you measure development speed you may end up hurting quality. 

I’m talking about during the process of growth and discovery in transformation. I’m not saying never care about speed but that is just not the first thing I would seek to transform normally.

They both matter but if we have to hit both we may hit neither. We may not even try if it looks impossible. Personally, I think in a transformation quality should be more important than speed. Organizations need to learn to go slow in order to speed up.

However, this is a choice, a preference on my part and you may choose to measure speed. The implication is when you have optimized quality your overall speed and capacity should increase since less defects and customer issues. Yet, if you measure development speed you may end up hurting quality.
I’m talking about during the process of growth and discovery in transformation. I’m not saying never care about speed but that is just not the first thing I would seek to transform normally.

Hi everyone,
I'm working in a company that has 3 working on the same tech-stack upgrade project consisting of backend devs and a tester. The main stakeholders are CTO and Tech Architect, however there is interest from board-level over project progress.
As the teams are solely backend and focuses on the upgrade, when it comes to the sprint review, the teams struggle with what to demo and what to show. We've gone through a few iterations of the session and the best thing we've landed on so far is the CTO reading the sprint goals at the start of the sprint and writing a one-liner about what he would like to see/know at the end of the sprint. This has worked a few times in a row but it's become difficult now the CTO decided to stop doing that.
Does anyone have a similar experience and/or got some format ideas we can try?
Thanks all
